8.25.text:
"Thank you, thank you very much.  It’s
great to be here in Slough, where so many

12.90.text:
– what?  Hold on a second.  This is actually
the town where so many businesses have their

20.94.text:
European headquarters, where so many jobs
have been created, and I think it’s a very

25.22.text:
good place to start the conversation we need
to have over the next four months about whether

30.11.text: Britain stays in the European Union or leaves.

33.50.text:
As Karen said, it’s also good to be starting
in a telecoms company.  This is a very successful

40.45.text:
business, but in an extraordinarily successful
industry.  200,000 people employed in the

45.69.text:
UK: you account for almost 2% of our economy,
so a great place to start.

51.87.text: Now, in four months’ time, we’re all going

53.83.text:
to have to make a very, very big decision:
does Britain stay in a reformed European Union

59.82.text:
or do we vote to leave?  Now, you make decisions
at election times, and I would argue this

65.35.text:
is a much bigger decision, because at election
times, you can vote in a team of people, and

70.64.text:
if you’re fed up with them after five years,
you can vote them out.  Obviously, I don’t

74.00.text: like that bit, but you can do that.

76.64.text:
This is a decision, though, that lasts for
life.  We make this decision, and it’s

82.35.text:
probably going to be the only time in our
generation when we make this decision.  And

87.21.text:
I was determined to make sure the British
people had the very best possible decision.

92.62.text:
So what I’ve done for the last nine months
is to try and sort out some of the things

97.63.text:
that people are frustrated with, with the
European Union.  Because it’s not a perfect

103.94.text:
And I thought that the four things that most
frustrated people about the European Union

108.90.text:
was that it’s been too bureaucratic and
not competitive enough, so we got a proper

114.48.text:
set of actions to make sure we take burdens
off business and create jobs and sign trade

119.47.text:
deals around the world.  I’ve sensed – and
I think many people have sensed – that it’s

123.35.text:
been too much of a political union, too much
about the politics, and not about creating

128.88.text:
jobs and prosperity.  So we’ve got Britain
carved out of an ever-closer union, so we

134.34.text:
don’t have to take part in those things
anymore.

137.02.text: I’ve sensed – I think a lot of people

139.24.text:
have sensed – that it’s been too much
of a single-currency club.  The euro is tremendously

143.68.text:
important for those countries in it, but those
countries out of it like Britain, we want

148.18.text:
to make sure we’re treated fairly inside
the European Union, so we have fixed that

153.48.text:
to make sure we can never be discriminated
against.

156.26.text: And the fourth thing I wanted to fix was to

158.49.text:
make sure that, of course we have free movement
in Europe: you can live and work and travel

164.52.text:
and retire in different European countries. 
But we need to take some of the pressure off

169.93.text:
in terms of migration, and specifically, we
need to have greater control over our own

173.99.text:
welfare system.  So I’ve managed to secure
the agreement that people who come to Britain

178.94.text:
and work, they’re going to have to come
and work for four years before they get full

182.97.text:
access to our welfare systems.  Now, I’m
not saying I’ve solved all the problems

187.19.text:
that Britain’s got with Europe, or all Europe’s
problems, but I think this is a good basis

191.50.text:
to now ask people, ‘Do you want to stay
in this reformed Europe or do you want to

197.92.text:
And I think when we come to this, the really
big question, I think there are three very

202.39.text:
positive reasons for wanting to stay inside
this reformed European Union.  The first

208.38.text:
is, that I believe we’ll be better off,
that we’ll create more jobs, we’ll create

213.02.text:
more livelihoods, we’ll see more investment,
we’ll see more success for Britain.  Why?

217.98.text:
Well, because we’re part, inside the European
Union, of the biggest free-trade single market

223.83.text:
anywhere in the world: 500 million people,
bigger than the US, bigger than China’s

229.37.text:
internal market.  This is the wealthiest,
strongest market in the world, and we have

234.94.text:
privileged access, without tariffs, the ability
to trade and invest right across the EU.

242.03.text: And I think about it from O2’s point of

244.03.text:
you.  Because we’ve got a set of rules
about telecommunications and mobile phones

250.89.text:
and the rest of it, that’s been good for
business because we’ve been able to break

254.74.text:
down barriers in other countries and set up
businesses in other countries.  That’s

259.09.text:
good for jobs, because we’re creating more
jobs, including right here in Slough.  But

263.78.text:
it’s also good for consumers, because this
competition inside the single market has actually

269.47.text:
driven down prices and it’s cheaper now;
much cheaper to use a mobile phone today than

274.73.text:
it was a decade ago.  And also, with the
end of roaming, it’s going to be – which

279.34.text:
we’re getting in 2017, it will be cheaper
still when you travel.

283.78.text: So point one, I think we’ll be better off.

285.72.text:
Far better off inside the European Union. 
3 million jobs are dependent on our trade

292.49.text:
with Europe.  Now, of course, not all the
jobs would go if we left the European Union;

297.77.text:
we’d still do trade with Europe.  But can
we really put our hands on our hearts and

301.66.text:
say all those jobs would be safe, that we
wouldn’t be disadvantaged if we were on

305.55.text:
the outside?  I don’t believe we can, so
we’re better off.

308.82.text: The second reason is, I believe that we’ll

311.26.text:
be safer inside the European Union.  We obviously
face, in our world today, some very big threats

317.72.text:
in terms of crime and terrorism, and obviously
the primary thing we do there is we have a

322.80.text:
strong police force, we have security and
intelligence services, we work with our longstanding

327.58.text:
partners like America to try and keep our
people and keep our country safe.  But I

332.32.text:
can tell you, as your Prime Minister, I’ve
seen so many times how the border information

337.77.text:
we exchange with other European countries,
how the criminal records information we exchange

342.95.text:
with other countries, this helps to keep us
safe.

346.04.text: Let me just give you one example.  We all

349.23.text:
remember those terrible days in 2005 when
London was bombed by terrorists.  The second

356.46.text:
time that was attempted, on 21st July, one
of those bombers got out of the country, but

363.59.text:
because we were part of the European Arrest
Warrant, we were able to get him arrested,

368.61.text:
get him back to the UK, and he’s now sitting
doing a 40-year jail sentence.  Before we

374.52.text:
had the European Arrest Warrant, before we
had those arrangements, it could take years,

378.92.text:
sometimes as much as a decade, to get people
extradited from other European countries back

384.55.text:
here, so we will be safer inside the reformed
European Union.

389.52.text: I also believe we’ll be stronger.  I believe

392.22.text:
profoundly that Britain is not the sort of
country that simply looks inward on itself.

396.89.text:
We know that we should have a role in the
world, because we will be stronger and safer

402.93.text:
and better off if we can actually get things
done around our world.  And as part of the

409.08.text:
European Union, just as being part of NATO
or part of the United Nations, we can get

414.31.text:
things done.  How did we get those oil sanctions
against Iran, so they gave up their nuclear

420.34.text:
weapons?  We did that inside the EU.  How
have we made sure we’ve had a strong response

425.85.text:
to Vladimir Putin and what he’s trying to
do in the Ukraine?  We’ve had sanctions

430.40.text:
set out inside the EU.  How have we stopped
our ships being attacked as they go round

436.31.text:
the coast of Africa and Somalia?  We’ve
done that through NATO, but also through the

441.48.text:
EU.  So I believe we are stronger in the
world if we are part of a reformed European Union.

450.99.text:
But I think we have to recognise in this decision
you’re all going to take in four months’

455.69.text:
time, that it is a choice.  I’ve set out
the positive choice of why I think we’re

460.84.text:
better off, stronger and safer, but we also
need to ask ourselves, what would it look

465.46.text:
like outside the EU?  And here I think we
need some answers from the people making the

471.51.text:
other case, because right now, they’re not
telling us what it’s going to be like outside

476.00.text:
the EU.  I’ve looked at what the models
are.  You can have a situation like Norway.

481.10.text:
They sign up to all the rules of the EU, so
they have to pay into the EU, they have to

487.19.text:
take migration from the EU, but they have
no say on what the rules are.  That seems

492.06.text: to me a very, very poor deal.

494.63.text:
You could go to the other end of the spectrum,
and say, as I think Mr Farage did yesterday,

500.76.text:
‘Let’s just have the World Trade Organisation
rules and be a member of the World Trade Organisation

506.03.text:
outside the EU, and see what that means.’ 
Well, what that would mean is, you’d start

510.71.text:
having to pay tariffs every time you export
a car to Europe.  Britain, for instance,

516.82.text:
is now the third‑largest manufacturer of
cars in the EU: it employs 140,000 people.

523.63.text:
So I think we’ve got to look very carefully
at these alternatives, because each one of

527.79.text:
them shares a key disadvantage, which is that
basically, if you leave the EU, you no longer

534.57.text:
have any say over the rules, over the laws,
over the way this market works, and we are,

540.33.text:
in the end, a trading nation where our businesses
need access to that market and need a say

548.37.text:
When all is said and done, it’s not going
to be me that makes the choice; it’s going

552.31.text:
to be all of you.  This is a referendum where
every single vote counts the same.  But I

557.51.text:
just make two final pleas to you.  First
of all, I think what we can have now is the

563.12.text:
best of both worlds.  Inside the bits of
the EU that work for us, inside the single

568.92.text:
market, inside the political cooperation to
get things done, inside those things that

573.72.text:
keep us safe against terrorists and criminals,
but not in the single currency, not in the

579.35.text:
Schengen no-borders system, not in an ever-closer
political union.  We have the best of both

586.94.text:
Final thing from me is that I feel very strongly
about this.  I feel that having spent nine

592.49.text:
months trying to get us a better deal, securing
that deal, and now with four months to go

597.20.text:
before this referendum, I feel with all I’ve
seen in the last six years as your Prime Minister,

603.05.text:
the right decision is to stay in a reformed
EU.  I have no other agenda.  I’m not

609.38.text:
standing as your Prime Minister at the next
election.  I’m simply going to speak for

613.74.text:
the next four months about the advantages
I see of staying in and the dangers of coming

619.67.text:
out.  But in the end it will be your choice,
the British people’s choice.  If you choose

624.74.text:
to stay in, we know what we get.  If you
choose to leave, I will put in place the arrangements

630.78.text:
as your Prime Minister that you asked me to
do.  But my strong advice, with all that

636.08.text:
I’ve seen and all that I know, is the right
thing for Britain is to stay in a reformed

642.09.text: Europe and to cast that vote on 23rd June.

646.67.text:
Thank you very much and look forward to your
questions.

657.44.text: Now, we’ve got some time for questions if

660.49.text:
you put your hand up and there’ll be roving
microphones and if you wait for those.  You

665.14.text: may not need them, but just in case.

666.67.text: Let’s have the gentleman down here."

668.57.text:
"Hi there.  Thank you very much.  So just
a quick question.  Looking at BBC News the

672.82.text:
other day I noticed that the pound had gone
down about 2% against the dollar.  Just wondered

676.96.text:
what your thoughts were on, kind of the impact
on the British economy based on the speculation

681.81.text:
of a Brexit or a British exit from the EU? 
Also, the kind of long-term impact of that

687.28.text:
and also the short-term impact of that, and
I guess what you’re going to look to, to

691.79.text:
"Well look, I think it’s a very good point. 
I don’t think it’s necessarily right to

695.13.text:
speculate too much about what happens on the
markets one day against another, but the government

700.90.text:
will want to set out very clearly what we
think the economic impacts could be.  Obviously

706.57.text:
we know if we stay in a reformed European
Union we know what to expect.  We know how

711.92.text:
the market works, we know how to sell our
goods, we know how to create jobs, we know

715.65.text:
how the systems work.  If we leave, there
is this period of great uncertainty.  And

721.57.text:
that’s why I think there could be a bad
economic effect and what we’ll do is make

726.76.text:
sure that the treasury and the Bank of England
and other authoritative organisations set

731.82.text:
out the facts, set out the figures so people
can make a judgement.

734.71.text: But I think the reason why there’d be a

738.37.text:
bad effect is quite simple: if you leave,
the process is you spend two years discussing

745.67.text:
the arrangements for leaving, and at the end
of those two years, unless there’s unanimous

751.06.text:
agreement by the other 27 members, you’re
automatically out of the European Union.

756.79.text:
And as you spend those two years negotiating
what your position will be like outside the

761.50.text:
EU, you can’t really do the trade deals
with other countries that we have today.

766.56.text:
So I think there’ll be big uncertainty for
businesses.  And that’s why I think, if

769.84.text:
you believe in voting to leave you’ve got
to really believe it. You’ve got to feel

773.69.text:
very, very strongly this is the right answer
because I think there’ll be a lot of uncertainty

777.93.text:
and businesses will be saying, ‘Well what
are the rules for exporting, what is our access

782.37.text:
to the single market, how certain can we be?’ 
And that’s why I’m so pleased that O2

786.70.text:
today has come out very strongly in support
of staying in a reformed European Union.

791.98.text:
We’ve got 35 of the biggest businesses in
Britain who’ve all said that they think

797.12.text:
Britain is better off.  Nissan, the car company
– and we make more cars now in the North East of

802.00.text:
England than the whole of Italy because of
the great success of Nissan.  And they’ve

806.39.text:
said this today, ‘For us, a position of
stability is more positive than a collection

811.47.text:
of unknowns.’  And I think that is worth
listening to.

814.32.text: Obviously we’ve got to listen to other voices

815.92.text:
as well, but when we listen to businesses
we’re not just listening to what some big

821.79.text:
business chief might say, we’re actually
listening to the effect on jobs, to the effect

826.12.text:
on families’ finances, to the effect on
the prosperity for our country and for all

831.16.text:
Okay, let’s go to some – let’s have
a question from up here."

837.41.text:
"Sorry.  What do you see the potential advantage
is for us leaving?  I know you talk about

843.21.text:
advantages of us staying, but if we were to
leave, what would you see as the advantages?"

847.70.text: "I think those who want to leave should speak

850.86.text:
about those, but chiefly what they point to,
I think, is this idea that obviously if you

856.39.text:
leave the EU you are able to make more decisions
for yourself because you’re not taking part

864.18.text:
in the decisions in the EU that cover a lot
of areas of regulation or legislation, such

870.08.text:
as the laws that for instance govern mobile
phones in Europe.  I think, look, that is

876.35.text:
true but you’ve got to ask yourself, does
that make you more powerful?  Does it make

882.30.text:
you genuinely more sovereign?  Because the
fact is if you leave the EU the EU doesn’t

888.72.text:
So let’s take your industry.  If we were
to leave, you’d still have the European Union

895.06.text:
making rules about mobile phone coverage,
technology and all the rest of it.  We’d

899.68.text:
be on the outside and if we wanted to sell
into the EU we’d still have to obey the

904.93.text:
rules that were being written.  The difference
is that we wouldn’t be writing them.

908.39.text: Now some people say, ‘Yes, but you never

909.73.text:
get to write the rules, you’re not that
powerful in Europe.’  Well Britain is the

913.55.text:
second largest economy, the second largest
net contributor and we do make a real impact

920.29.text:
on those rules.  In fact, I would argue,
if you take your industry, if we weren’t

924.71.text:
there I think Europe would come probably more
protectionist, less open, it’d be less easy

930.61.text:
for companies like O2 to break into other
European markets.  So I think what you’d

935.34.text:
be left with, if we were to leave, is a sense
that you might feel a bit more sovereign about

941.52.text:
making your own decisions, but you wouldn’t
actually be able to make the decisions that

946.01.text: make a difference to people’s lives.

947.75.text:
So I think you get more power and influence
in than you get from the illusion of sovereignty,

953.26.text:
out.  But I think that’s going to be one
of the key questions in this campaign.

956.82.text: Let’s have one from the press.  We’ll

960.67.text:
"Thank you very much, Prime Minister.  Thank
you.  I notice it’s not very fashionable

966.34.text:
to wear a tie around here.  You and I are
a little –"

971.22.text:
"– a little outnumbered.  Listen, my question
is this: a former Tory leader today, William

974.64.text:
Hague who knows all about splits on Europe,
warned about the dangers ahead in the coming

978.10.text:
months, and that’s partly because a man
who wants to be Tory leader, Boris Johnson,

982.16.text:
will be campaigning on the other side to you. 
When you said yesterday you have no other

986.97.text:
agenda, and you’ve repeated that here today,
we all know you were talking about Boris Johnson,

991.09.text: will you at least admit that?"

992.87.text:
"No, look I would…  I’m saying this because
I feel this so strongly.  Right?  I’m

1000.93.text:
not standing again as Prime Minister and I
just want people to know that I am speaking

1005.76.text:
about this issue after thinking about it very,
very deeply.  After thinking about all the

1010.81.text:
things I’ve learnt as Prime Minister over
the last six years.

1014.71.text: I think 6, 10, 15 years ago, I don’t think

1017.95.text:
that I believed that Europe was as important
to our security as I believe it is today because

1023.79.text:
I’ve seen with my own eyes just how important
this security and intelligence and sharing

1030.70.text:
I’m not sure that six maybe ten years ago
I thought that Europe was quite so important

1037.04.text:
for Britain getting things done in the world. 
I thought obviously NATO matters, our partnership

1042.60.text:
with America matters, but I see and I’ve
seen this for six years that if we want to

1047.19.text:
fix stuff, whether it is trying to stop people
smugglers in the Mediterranean, whether it’s

1053.24.text:
trying to stop pirates off the coast of Africa,
whether it’s confronting Iran about the

1057.44.text:
nuclear programme, whether it’s trying to
get better results in Syria, we gain by sitting

1063.72.text:
round that table with the French, with the
Germans, with the Italians and getting things

1068.74.text:
Look, we can do great things on our own. 
We’ve got amazing armed forces, brilliant

1071.80.text:
intelligence services, we’re the fifth biggest
economy in the world, we’re a great power.

1076.66.text:
But we get more by being in these organisations
and I want to speak very clearly about that

1080.95.text:
because I feel this, with my experience over
the last six years, very, very deeply

1085.54.text: Now let me say about Boris, I have huge respect

1088.59.text:
for Boris as a politician.  He’s a great
friend of mine.  He is a fantastic Mayor

1093.25.text:
of London.  I think he’s got a lot to give
to the Conservative party.  I think he’s

1097.13.text:
got a lot to give to this country.  But on
this issue I think he’s got it wrong and

1101.49.text:
I think he’s reached the wrong conclusion. 
So we’re going to have, I hope, a very reasonable,

1106.51.text:
civilised argument, both between us and between
other parties, and you’re going to find

1111.24.text:
people with some fairly strange bedfellows. 
This is one where, you know, Jeremy Corbyn

1116.17.text:
and I agree.  I mean, we don’t agree about
many things but we agree about this one.

1120.57.text: So we just have to have a debate, and yes

1123.60.text:
of course it’s going to be a strong and
a passionate debate, and I think he’s got

1128.54.text:
this one wrong.  And I would say to anybody
who is thinking about this and is struggling

1136.03.text:
to decide, because I think lots of people,
I think we all feel quite conflicted.  In

1140.36.text:
all of us there’s a questioning about what’s
the right answer for Britain.  I would say:

1145.17.text:
anyone who’s finding it hard to make up
your mind, and you feel it’s a very balanced

1150.41.text:
decision, I would say come down on the side
of security and safety and certainty.  Because

1156.95.text:
in this reformed European Union we know what
we get.  We know what we get in terms of

1161.77.text:
jobs and prosperity and security.  Outside,
what do we get?  And I don’t think the

1167.54.text:
people who want us to leave are spelling it
out.

1170.76.text: Yesterday in Parliament it was quite interesting.

1173.43.text:
Not only do the people who want to leave,
not only are they not sure about what they

1177.40.text:
want to do when they’ve left, i.e. do you
want to have a Norway-style solution or do

1182.28.text:
you want a world trade solution or do you
want a trade deal?  They haven’t worked

1186.52.text:
that one out but they’re also not sure about
how they even want to leave or indeed in some

1192.15.text:
cases whether they really do want to leave. 
Some people are suggesting, maybe if we vote

1197.47.text:
no, we can have a second renegotiation, we
can have a second referendum, and I think

1202.14.text:
that is a complete illusion.  This is a straight
decision: you stay in or you get out, and

1208.51.text:
I think it’s misleading people if we pretend
there’s some other answer here.

1214.14.text: So I think Boris has got this wrong.  I have

1216.43.text:
huge respect for him; I think he’s got a
very strong future in British politics.

1220.21.text:
But on this one, I think he’s made the wrong
decision.

1223.90.text: Now, let’s have gentleman over here."

1227.59.text: "Welcome to O2, Prime Minister.  You mentioned

1231.54.text:
the European Union, and you mentioned that
the UK is the world’s fifth-biggest economy,

1236.11.text:
it’s the second-biggest economy in the EU
and the second-biggest contributor.  There

1240.64.text:
are those who say that the EU cannot credibly
continue without us in it, and that if we

1247.39.text:
were to vote for Brexit, it would lead to
the EU’s breakup, which the UK could end

1253.18.text:
up being a haven for investors and so on. 
How would you respond to that argument?

1256.98.text:
We hear a lot about the impact on the UK,
but what do you think the impact could be

1260.52.text:
on the EU and the implications for the UK
if we vote for Brexit?"

1264.89.text:
"It’s a very good question.  I think the
impact on the EU, I’d say two points about

1268.65.text:
that.  One is, I think it would weaken the
West at a time of great concern and conflict.

1276.29.text:
We’ve got Putin to the east, we’ve got
Daesh in Syria and Iraq, and problems of terrorism.

1282.99.text:
This – it’s a time, I think, for strength
in numbers.  It’s not a time for dividing

1286.98.text:
the West.  So in that respect, it would make
the EU weaker and make the West weaker.

1293.60.text: But the other thing I’d say is, I don’t

1295.83.text:
believe – some people believe if Britain
left the EU, the whole thing would sort of

1298.42.text:
collapse.  I don’t think that is the case. 
I think actually, what would happen is the

1303.61.text:
EU would probably become more protectionist. 
I think it would probably become more politically

1309.77.text:
integrated.  I think it would probably want
to take even more decisions over people’s

1314.52.text:
lives, and those decisions would affect us. 
I think this is one of the key points; one

1319.20.text:
of my cabinet ministers said at the cabinet
meeting, you know, ‘We’d all like to be

1325.18.text:
in Utopia, but I guess when we get to Utopia,
we might find the EU’s there already.’

1328.11.text:
You know, this thing doesn’t cease to exist
because we leave it, and I think it would

1333.25.text:
And if you take your industry specifically,
you know, Britain has been a great force in

1337.88.text:
Europe and continues to be a great force in
Europe for opening up markets, for saying

1342.36.text:
that other countries should liberalise their
telecoms sectors and allow in new companies,

1347.85.text:
just as we’ve done here.  And I think that
if we’re not there making that point, less

1353.01.text:
of that will happen, and that is bad news
for British telecoms companies.  So I think

1358.22.text:
it would be a worse Europe if we’re not
there, but at the same time, I think we’d

1362.35.text:
be showing disunity at a time when we need
strength in numbers for the security of our

1367.74.text:
Let’s have a few more questions, and then
we’re – gentleman over here."

1374.31.text: "Hi, Mr Cameron.  We’ve obviously had the

1378.76.text:
blond bombshell of Mr Johnson coming out and
supporting the ‘leave’ campaign.  Also,

1384.16.text:
I noticed today that almost two thirds of
FTSE 100 CEOs didn’t sign a letter to suggest

1392.04.text:
we should stay in the EU.  Are you concerned
there’s increasing momentum going towards

1399.48.text:
"I think it’s going to be a very hard-fought
contest.  I think that, you know, they’re

1404.27.text:
very strong arguments on both sides; there’ll
be very strong figures on both sides.  But

1409.74.text:
I think when it comes to business and industry,
the overwhelming view I am getting is that

1416.64.text:
British business, particularly those that
trade a lot with Europe, really want us to

1422.58.text:
stay in the EU.  And for 35 FTSE 100 companies
to come out and say this so clearly as they

1430.81.text:
have today, I think that is a very positive,
very clear decision by them and a very clear

1438.20.text:
message, that they’re saying, ‘We’ll
be better off if we stay in.’  And, you

1443.64.text:
know, for companies these days to make a statement
like that, they find that sometimes quite

1449.55.text:
difficult; they have to go through corporate
governance proceedings, board meetings, to

1453.34.text:
make those decisions.  And many businesses
don’t want to get involved in any political

1458.37.text:
But I would say to them: this is not like
a general election.  It’s not about backing

1462.50.text:
one team or another team.  This is a decision
that we’re going to have to live with in

1466.71.text:
Britain for decades to come, and so if you
have a strong view, you should make it clear.

1471.92.text:
But I think it’s a – I can’t remember
before 35 FTSE 100 companies coming out

1476.67.text:
in this way quite so clearly.  So I’m convinced
the strongest arguments are on the ‘remain’

1481.85.text:
side, and I’m going to use everything I’ve
got in the next four months to put those arguments,

1485.52.text: because I believe this is so important.

1488.30.text:
"Thank you very much indeed.  And sorry,
as I’m wearing a tie, too.  Prime Minister,

1500.85.text:
the business letter which was raised by the
previous questioner, isn’t the era of business

1506.60.text:
leaders telling the British people how to
vote over?  Shouldn’t this be a debate

1510.92.text:
about the strength of people’s arguments,
not their share prices?

1513.95.text: And secondly, if I may, can you just be more

1516.77.text:
– answer that question a little bit more
fully: why do you think so few other business

1522.76.text:
leaders, those other two thirds, didn’t
sign your letter?  Because I know that you

1527.95.text:
"Well, first of all, I would say it is a huge
number of FTSE 100 companies, the 100 biggest

1533.78.text:
companies in the country, coming out and being
so clear that Britain is better off remaining

1539.72.text:
in a reformed Europe.  That’s a very clear
statement.  As I say, one of the reasons

1543.90.text:
companies often find it hard to go forward
is that they sometimes have to have board

1547.98.text:
meetings and sometimes don’t want to make
any form of political statement.  But I can

1552.17.text:
tell you this: if the ‘leave’ campaign
could produce 35 business leaders of this

1557.89.text:
statute – of this sort of stature, they’d
be over the moon.  And I don’t think they

1561.86.text:
have the prospect of doing that with FTSE
100 leaders in any way like what has happened

1568.20.text:
Now, I would argue, this is not business leaders
telling people how to vote.  This is simply

1574.02.text:
people running some of the largest businesses
in our country that employ over 1 million

1578.86.text:
people between them, saying this has real
consequences for our country, and if we care

1584.06.text:
about jobs, if we care about investment, if
we care about a strong British economy, then

1589.61.text:
the right decision is to remain in the EU,
and I would encourage, not just businesses,

1595.20.text:
I’d encourage trade unions to speak out,
I’d encourage voluntary bodies, non‑governmental

1601.39.text:
organisations, universities, anyone who thinks
this is important.  If you think it affects

1606.19.text:
your business, affects jobs, affects the way
that you think Britain can do well or badly

1612.02.text:
in the world, speak out.  This is a really,
really important decision.  We’re going

1616.23.text:
to take it in four months, and it’s going
to last for decades, so I don’t think anyone

1620.45.text:
should hold back.  I’m certainly not going
to hold back, and I think that anyone who

1624.75.text: thinks this is important: speak out.

1626.89.text: Okay, lady – yes, let’s have Sophy."

1630.28.text:
"Cheers.  Sophy Ridge, Sky News.  I was
wondering if you could take us back to the

1637.34.text:
moment when you found out that Boris Johnson
was going to campaign for the other side,

1641.67.text:
as you.  How did you find out, and were you
irritated or were you just disappointed?"

1646.42.text: "No, I – you know, I’ve been talking to

1648.46.text:
Boris for many weeks about this issue.  We’ve
had lots of long conversations about it, lots

1654.50.text:
of text messages and emails and face-to-face
conversations about it.  And look, I – of

1660.45.text:
course I’m disappointed, because I want
everyone possible to back my side of the argument,

1666.26.text:
and I believe in it very passionately, and
so obviously I’m disappointed.  But I understand

1671.17.text:
there are lots of people who, you know, have
very strong views about this.

1675.27.text: But I would say to anyone who’s taking time

1677.98.text:
to decide, who’s thinking about it and weighing
it up and trying to work out what’s best,

1682.11.text:
if you’re not certain, surely the best thing
to do is to back the side that has the security

1690.53.text:
and the safety and the certainty of what we
know.  Because it is undoubtedly true that

1697.65.text:
voting to leave is a risk.  Even if you think
there’s going to be some great future at

1704.40.text:
the end of the process – and I don’t buy
that – there’s undoubtedly a period of

1709.46.text:
risk and uncertainty.  You’ve got two years
when you have to negotiate what your leaving

1716.33.text:
looks like.  During that period, you can’t
go around signing trade deals with other countries,

1721.35.text:
and when you leave, what is your relationship
going to be with the single market on which

1726.72.text:
so many jobs depend?  What will be the decision
of businesses thinking about where to invest

1732.11.text:
in Europe, about whether they should come
to Britain?

1734.91.text: Here we are in a telecoms firm, but let’s

1737.16.text:
take another example, let’s take financial
services, an important industry.  Right now,

1742.07.text:
all those businesses know what they’ve got. 
They know that if you are located in Britain,

1747.69.text:
because we’re a member of the EU, you can
sell your services in every other EU country.

1752.98.text:
Now, if we leave the EU, we may not have that,
and so those companies, if they’re only

1760.03.text:
based in Britain, would have to move some
jobs into other EU countries.  Overseas companies

1766.15.text:
thinking of coming here would think, ‘Well,
why come to Britain?  Because I don’t get

1771.04.text:
that right to passport all my services throughout
the rest of the EU.  I’d better go somewhere

1775.86.text:
else.’  So it seems to me there’s a real
danger of job losses, in that industry and

1784.21.text:
Plus, I think you’ve got to think something
else.  If you’re not in the single market,

1790.56.text:
what is the danger of the countries of the
single market discriminating against you?

1796.76.text:
Right now, we have recourse to stop that. 
Europe the other day did actually try, very

1801.79.text:
annoyingly, to say that if you wanted to do
complex deals in euros, you had to be in a

1806.90.text:
eurozone country.  That was really bad news
for Britain but we fought it, through the

1812.79.text:
courts, and we won, and in my renegotiation
we’ve set out a principal that means that

1817.75.text:
can never happen again.  But leave the single
market, leave the European Union, yes we’d

1823.36.text:
still have a great financial services industry,
London’s an amazing financial centre, but

1827.64.text:
they could start discriminating against us
from day one.  And what recourse would we

1833.32.text:
So these are the questions and that’s why
I say there is uncertainty, there is risk,

1837.27.text:
there is a leap in the dark if you leave the
single market and leave the EU, so if you’re

1842.65.text:
not certain, don’t leap.  Stay with what
we’ve got, knowing it’s going to get better

1847.35.text:
because of the deal I negotiated with the
EU which does address some of the biggest

1852.66.text: concerns we’ve had in our country.

1854.60.text:
Let’s have a few more, let’s have – trying
to get more of a gender balance here from

1859.41.text:
the – let’s have – okay.  I’m not
doing very well at this.  Lady up here.

1869.29.text:
They’re not going to let you ask your question,
I don’t know what it is, we’ve got to

1882.43.text:
"Hiya, so – so my question is in terms of
common man like – I am not part of Britain,

1892.50.text:
I come from overseas, so I see my neighbour
who’s a Polish guy who’s getting more

1898.51.text:
benefits than I’m supposed to get it, so
what is it like?"

1903.29.text: "I think this issue about benefits and welfare

1907.15.text:
and migration, I think is a really important
issue and I’ll be very level with you: part

1912.94.text:
of being in the European Union is accepting
the free movement of people.  That we are

1919.19.text:
able, in Britain, if we want, to go and work
and live, travel, retire in other European

1924.81.text:
countries, and other European countries can
come and do that here in Britain.  So there

1929.43.text:
is that free movement, but what there’s
not is the free movement to go and claim benefits.

1934.53.text:
If someone comes to Britain, if they – under
all the rules I’ve changed, if they come

1939.65.text:
to Britain, they can’t claim unemployment
benefit for the time they come.  If they

1944.56.text:
haven’t got a job after six months, they
have to go home because they can’t sustain

1948.84.text:
themselves.  And what we’ve now agreed
is that if you come and work, you don’t

1953.26.text:
get full access to our tax credits, our in-work
benefits for four years.  And also if you

1960.97.text:
claim child benefit, you can only claim child
benefit at a rate discounted for the country

1967.33.text:
you come from.  So I think these are good
changes, big changes which will have an effect

1972.03.text:
on this issue about welfare claiming and migration
that I think has concerned people in our country.

1977.86.text: But I’m not saying we’ve solved all the

1980.18.text:
problems, there still is pressure from freedom
of movement and that’s why we’ve made

1985.42.text:
some other changes as well, to make sure that
if people have – are criminals, we don’t

1990.74.text:
have to let them in, if there are people trying
to do sham marriages, that we can deal with

1994.45.text:
that.  A whole lot of changes to free movement,
and I think that’s really important because

1998.21.text:
people want to know there’s a basic sense
of fairness.  And I would say the thing people

2002.07.text:
most want to know is that there’s no something
for nothing.  You can’t come here and start

2006.76.text:
claiming benefits straight away, you’ve
got to pay into the system before you get

2010.47.text:
out of the system.  And that’s one of the
things that my renegotiation has secured.

2014.57.text: Okay, let’s have a few more, let’s have

2021.72.text:
"I just wanted to kind of ask a question about
ourselves as O2 and try and bring it to life

2031.58.text:
in that sense.  You might be aware that we’re
being acquired by Hutchison at the moment,

2036.64.text:
and BT EE’s transaction went through the
CMA, it was all fine, and then because we’re

2041.95.text:
foreign-owned, it’s going through a European
Commission body and they – probably it was

2046.22.text:
different political or whatever agenda to
us.  I’m just wondering if you think that’s

2051.90.text:
"Okay, first thing is, the way this works
is that mergers, over a certain size, are

2057.58.text:
looked at by the European Union.  It’s
not because you’re owned by a foreign‑owned

2062.55.text:
country, it’s because of the scale of the
merger that’s being contemplated.  Now

2066.64.text:
I must make no comment on it, it’s not up
to me, it’s up to independent competition

2070.95.text:
bodies, both here in the UK and in the EU. 
So they will have to decide, and I was talking

2077.24.text:
to your Chief Executive about this; they’ll
have to decide whether it is good for competition

2082.11.text: and all the rest of it, or not.

2084.01.text:
What I would say though, just come back to
how this impacts your industry: this has been,

2088.10.text:
and is, an unbelievable success story.  You
think about – go back 10, 20 years, how

2094.41.text:
many people were employed in mobile telephony,
now we’re talking about 200,000 people,

2100.32.text:
the spawning of huge numbers of different
industries around what you do, with all the

2105.74.text:
games and the applications and all the rest
of it.

2107.76.text: And I would argue that, for your industry,

2110.53.text:
of course we’d still have a great mobile
phone market in Britain if we were outside

2114.75.text:
the EU, of course we’d still have great
mobile phone companies, but would we have

2119.15.text:
the opportunities to use these rules in Europe
to break up the monopolies in other countries

2125.03.text:
and make sure that O2 can be a success in
those countries too?  We wouldn’t, and

2129.23.text:
I think they’d go in the opposite direction. 
And when I look around Europe and telecoms

2134.61.text:
markets, so many of them are still dominated
by the old legacy nationalised company.

2141.88.text:
And actually we’ve shown in Britain that
a more competitive market means lower prices,

2146.10.text:
better services, much more innovation.  And
we want to drive that right across the EU.

2150.45.text:
We’ve got a chance to lead the EU in this
industry.  Indeed, some of the best companies

2156.86.text:
have been born and bred right here in Britain
and I want them to be able to, you know, paint

2161.99.text:
on the larger canvas and create the jobs,
more of which we want to see here.

2165.99.text: Last question I’m afraid.  Lady here."

2170.57.text: "You’ve talked a lot about big business

2174.86.text:
but I’m interested to know, as a strong
supporter of small business, do you really

2181.40.text: think that being in the EU is better for them?"

2183.89.text:
"Very good question.  Okay we’ve done a
lot of arguments about a big company like

2187.77.text:
O2, and what it means.  What about small
companies?  I’d make a couple of points.

2192.42.text:
First of all, about one in five small companies
export, and most of them will be exporting

2198.92.text:
to Europe as well as other countries.  And
there the same arguments apply.  If you are

2205.15.text:
going to sell into Europe, you’ve got to
meet the rules of the single market.  So

2210.17.text:
if you’re outside the EU, you still have
to meet those rules, but you have no say on

2214.09.text:
what they are.  And I think Britain can be
a force for good, in Europe, in terms of making

2219.70.text:
sure the rules are fair, and making sure we
cut bureaucracy.  And one of the things I

2223.62.text:
secured in my agreement, the special status
for Britain, is that we are going to have

2228.64.text:
targets to cut bureaucracy in each of the
main business areas, which I think will help

2235.29.text:
I’d also make this point: many small businesses
that don’t export are part of a supply chain

2242.16.text:
with companies that do export, and so I think
that the idea that there are two sorts of

2247.28.text:
businesses, one entirely domestic and one
international and exporting, I think is rather

2254.10.text:
Now those who want to leave will argue of
course if you’re outside the EU then you’ve

2260.88.text:
got to meet the single market rules when you
sell into Europe but you could deregulate

2264.84.text:
your rules here in the UK.  But there I would
say: is that really worth that much?  When

2271.62.text:
you look at all the international surveys,
they say that Britain is one of the best places

2276.30.text:
in the world to start a business, to run a
business, to comply with regulation and the

2281.73.text:
rest of it.  So I don’t think the benefit
you get out of being outside the EU, on that

2288.18.text:
basis, is worth anything like the giving up
of the influence and the rules in the single

2293.30.text:
market on which we do rely.  The figures
are very straight forward: 50% of what we

2299.85.text:
export goes to other EU countries; 7% of what
they export comes to us, so when some people

2307.60.text:
say, ‘Well we’ve got a trade deficit with
Europe, so they need us more than we need

2312.37.text: them,’ I think they’re making a mistake.

2315.76.text:
We obviously are a global country, we trade
all over the world, we’ve doubled our exports

2320.92.text:
to China, and we need small businesses to
play a part in that too.  And we shouldn’t

2324.92.text:
be choosing between either doing better in
the Far East, the Middle East, China, America,

2331.47.text:
the Commonwealth, we shouldn’t be choosing
between that and doing well in Europe.  We

2335.49.text:
should try and do both.  Let’s be in the
single market, trading effectively with other

2341.41.text:
European countries and increasing jobs and
growth.  And at the same time getting out

2345.22.text:
there and taking on the world in the way that
we have with China and India and other countries.

2349.64.text: Look I really enjoyed coming today, thank

2352.18.text:
you for being so patient with me and thank
you very much indeed.  Thanks a lot."
